title: ‘The toughest week of my life’
text:
Grant Hackett breaks silence, thanks family after ‘toughest week’ Greg Stolz, The Courier-Mail Hackett’s fall mirrors Phelps’s 
GRANT Hackett has broken his silence since his dramatic arrest last week, thanking his family for “helping me through the toughest week of my life”. 
Hackett today released an emotional statement thanking his family and the public for their support and pleading for privacy to battle his personal problems. 
“I want to thank my family, in particular my mum and dad for helping me through the toughest week of my life,” Hackett said. 
“They have been amazing and have now stood by me through thick and thin — I can’t say enough about them — I could not wish for better parents. 
“My brother and I have reconnected and love each other very much — our family has always been our priority. 
“Also the support I have received from so many people in Australia and around the world has also been incredible. I wish I could reply to every single message or well wish I’ve had, which is impossible at present, as I’m so grateful for each and every one of them. Hackett found safe after disappearance 2:34 
Police have confirmed Grant Hackett has been found safe after his family reported him missing. February 17th 2017 /video/video.news.com.au/News/ Hackett found safe after disappearance 
“This is a very private matter that I am going through and I am going to work my way through it. I would appreciate it if everyone would allow me and my family to do everything we need to do. 
“I know I have some mental health issues and I am seeking help here in Australia and I will be also going overseas. 
“I will not be talking to media during this time but I urge everyone to please give my family and myself the privacy and respect we need at this delicate time.” media_camera Hackett’s black-eyed selfie 
Hackett yesterday deleted a social media post alleging his brother “beat the s---” out of him. 
The selfie, which showed him sporting a black eye, had been posted to Instagram a day after his dramatic arrest following a violent meltdown at his family home. 
He alleged his older brother Craig was an “angry man” who had beaten him up. 
Craig had publicly vented the family’s frustrations at the Olympic champion’s dramatic downward spiral. 
“My brother comments to the media ... but does anyone know he beat the s--- out of me,” Hackett posted last Thursday. 
“Everyone knows he is an angry man.” 
The post, which Craig Hackett has declined to respond to, has now been taken down.
